author: virgil

0.1: reclining, on the slender oat rehearse
0.2: your silvan ditties: I from my sweet fields,
0.3: and home's familiar bounds, even now depart.
0.4: Exiled from home am I; while, Tityrus, you
0.5: sit careless in the shade, and, at your call,
0.8: this ease to us, for him a god will I
0.9: deem ever, and from my folds a tender lamb
0.10: oft with its life-blood shall his altar stain.
0.11: His gift it is that, as your eyes may see,
0.12: my kine may roam at large, and I myself
0.13: play on my shepherd's pipe what songs I will.
0.14: I grudge you not the boon, but marvel more,
0.15: such wide confusion fills the country-side.
0.16: See, sick at heart I drive my she-goats on,
0.17: and this one, O my Tityrus, scarce can lead:
0.18: for 'mid the hazel-thicket here but now
0.19: she dropped her new-yeaned twins on the bare flint,
0.20: hope of the flock—an ill, I mind me well,
0.21: which many a time, but for my blinded sense,
0.22: the thunder-stricken oak foretold, oft too
0.23: from hollow trunk the raven's ominous cry.
0.24: But who this god of yours? Come, Tityrus, tell.
0.25: The city, Meliboeus, they call Rome ,
0.26: I, simpleton, deemed like this town of ours,
0.27: whereto we shepherds oft are wont to drive
0.28: the younglings of the flock: so too I knew
0.29: whelps to resemble dogs, and kids their dams,
0.30: comparing small with great; but this as far
0.31: above all other cities rears her head
0.32: as cypress above pliant osier towers.
0.33: And what so potent cause took you to Rome ?
0.34: Freedom, which, though belated, cast at length
0.35: her eyes upon the sluggard, when my beard
0.36: 'gan whiter fall beneath the barber's blade—
0.37: cast eyes, I say, and, though long tarrying, came,
0.38: now when, from Galatea's yoke released,
0.39: I serve but Amaryllis: for I will own,
0.40: while Galatea reigned over me, I had
0.41: no hope of freedom, and no thought to save.
0.42: Though many a victim from my folds went forth,
0.43: or rich cheese pressed for the unthankful town,
0.44: never with laden hands returned I home.
0.45: I used to wonder, Amaryllis, why
0.46: you cried to heaven so sadly, and for whom
0.47: you left the apples hanging on the trees;
0.49: the very pines, the very water-springs,
0.50: the very vineyards, cried aloud for you.
0.51: What could I do? how else from bonds be freed,
0.52: or otherwhere find gods so nigh to aid?
0.53: There, Meliboeus, I saw that youth to whom
0.54: yearly for twice six days my altars smoke.
0.55: There instant answer gave he to my suit,
0.56: “Feed, as before, your kine, boys, rear your bulls.”
0.57: So in old age, you happy man, your fields
0.58: will still be yours, and ample for your need!
0.59: Though, with bare stones o'erspread, the pastures all
0.60: be choked with rushy mire, your ewes with young
0.61: by no strange fodder will be tried, nor hurt
0.62: through taint contagious of a neighbouring flock.
0.63: Happy old man, who 'mid familiar streams
0.64: and hallowed springs, will court the cooling shade!
0.65: Here, as of old, your neighbour's bordering hedge,
0.66: that feasts with willow-flower the Hybla bees,
0.67: shall oft with gentle murmur lull to sleep,
0.68: while the leaf-dresser beneath some tall rock
0.69: uplifts his song, nor cease their cooings hoarse
0.70: the wood-pigeons that are your heart's delight,
0.71: nor doves their moaning in the elm-tree top.
0.72: Sooner shall light stags, therefore, feed in air,
0.73: the seas their fish leave naked on the strand,
0.74: germans and Parthians shift their natural bounds,
0.75: and these the Arar , those the Tigris drink,
0.76: than from my heart his face and memory fade.
0.77: But we far hence, to burning Libya some,
0.78: some to the Scythian steppes, or thy swift flood,
0.79: cretan Oaxes, now must wend our way,
0.80: or Britain , from the whole world sundered far.
0.81: Ah! shall I ever in aftertime behold
0.82: my native bounds—see many a harvest hence
0.83: with ravished eyes the lowly turf-roofed cot
0.84: where I was king? These fallows, trimmed so fair,
0.85: some brutal soldier will possess these fields
0.86: an alien master. Ah! to what a pass
0.87: has civil discord brought our hapless folk!
0.88: For such as these, then, were our furrows sown!
0.89: Now, Meliboeus, graft your pears, now set
0.90: your vines in order! Go, once happy flock,
0.91: my she-goats, go. Never again shall I,
0.92: stretched in green cave, behold you from afar
0.93: hang from the bushy rock; my songs are sung;
0.94: never again will you, with me to tend,
0.95: on clover-flower, or bitter willows, browse.
0.96: Yet here, this night, you might repose with me,
0.97: on green leaves pillowed: apples ripe have I,
0.98: soft chestnuts, and of curdled milk enow.
0.99: And, see, the farm-roof chimneys smoke afar,
0.100: and from the hills the shadows lengthening fall!

1.0: the shepherd Corydon with love was fired
1.1: for fair Alexis, his own master's joy:
1.2: no room for hope had he, yet, none the less,
1.4: still would he haunt, and there alone, as thus,
1.5: to woods and hills pour forth his artless strains.
1.6: “Cruel Alexis, heed you naught my songs?
1.7: Have you no pity? you'll drive me to my death.
1.8: Now even the cattle court the cooling shade
1.9: and the green lizard hides him in the thorn:
1.10: now for tired mowers, with the fierce heat spent,
1.11: pounds Thestilis her mess of savoury herbs,
1.12: wild thyme and garlic. I, with none beside,
1.13: save hoarse cicalas shrilling through the brake,
1.14: still track your footprints 'neath the broiling sun.
1.15: Better have borne the petulant proud disdain
1.17: albeit he was so dark, and you so fair!
1.18: Trust not too much to colour, beauteous boy;
1.19: white privets fall, dark hyacinths are culled.
1.20: You scorn me, Alexis, who or what I am
1.21: care not to ask—how rich in flocks, or how
1.22: in snow-white milk abounding: yet for me
1.23: roam on Sicilian hills a thousand lambs;
1.24: summer or winter, still my milk-pails brim.
1.25: I sing as erst Amphion of Circe sang,
1.26: what time he went to call his cattle home
1.27: on Attic Aracynthus. Nor am I
1.28: so ill to look on: lately on the beach
1.29: I saw myself, when winds had stilled the sea,
1.30: and, if that mirror lie not, would not fear
1.31: daphnis to challenge, though yourself were judge.
1.32: Ah! were you but content with me to dwell.
1.33: Some lowly cot in the rough fields our home,
1.34: shoot down the stags, or with green osier-wand
1.35: round up the straggling flock! There you with me
1.36: in silvan strains will learn to rival Pan.
1.37: Pan first with wax taught reed with reed to join;
1.38: for sheep alike and shepherd Pan hath care.
1.39: Nor with the reed's edge fear you to make rough
1.40: your dainty lip; such arts as these to learn
1.41: what did Amyntas do?—what did he not?
1.42: A pipe have I, of hemlock-stalks compact
1.44: ‘Mine once,’ quoth he, ‘now yours, as heir to own.’
1.45: Foolish Amyntas heard and envied me.
1.46: Ay, and two fawns, I risked my neck to find
1.47: in a steep glen, with coats white-dappled still,
1.48: from a sheep's udders suckled twice a day—
1.49: these still I keep for you; which Thestilis
1.50: implores me oft to let her lead away;
1.51: and she shall have them, since my gifts you spurn.
1.52: Come hither, beauteous boy; for you the Nymphs
1.53: bring baskets, see, with lilies brimmed; for you,
1.55: now the fair Naiad, of narcissus flower
1.56: and fragrant fennel, doth one posy twine—
1.57: with cassia then, and other scented herbs,
1.58: blends them, and sets the tender hyacinth off
1.59: with yellow marigold. I too will pick
1.60: quinces all silvered-o'er with hoary down,
1.61: chestnuts, which Amaryllis wont to love,
1.62: and waxen plums withal: this fruit no less
1.63: shall have its meed of honour; and I will pluck
1.64: you too, ye laurels, and you, ye myrtles, near,
1.65: for so your sweets ye mingle. Corydon,
1.66: you are a boor, nor heeds a whit your gifts
1.67: alexis; no, nor would Iollas yield,
1.68: should gifts decide the day. Alack! alack!
1.69: What misery have I brought upon my head!—
1.70: loosed on the flowers Siroces to my bane,
1.71: and the wild boar upon my crystal springs!
1.72: Whom do you fly, infatuate? gods ere now,
1.73: and Dardan Paris, have made the woods their home.
1.74: Let Pallas keep the towers her hand hath built,
1.75: us before all things let the woods delight.
1.76: The grim-eyed lioness pursues the wolf,
1.77: the wolf the she-goat, the she-goat herself
1.78: in wanton sport the flowering cytisus,
1.79: and Corydon Alexis, each led on
1.80: by their own longing. See, the ox comes home
1.81: with plough up-tilted, and the shadows grow
1.82: to twice their length with the departing sun,
1.83: yet me love burns, for who can limit love?
1.84: Ah! Corydon, Corydon, what hath crazed your wit?
1.85: Your vine half-pruned hangs on the leafy elm;
1.86: why haste you not to weave what need requires
1.87: of pliant rush or osier? Scorned by this,
1.88: elsewhere some new Alexis you will find.”

2.0: Who owns the flock, Damoetas? Meliboeus?
2.1: Nay, they are Aegon's sheep, of late by him
2.4: unhappy sheep, unhappy flock! while he
2.5: still courts Neaera, fearing lest her choice
2.6: should fall on me, this hireling shepherd here
2.7: wrings hourly twice their udders, from the flock
2.8: filching the life-juice, from the lambs their milk.
2.9: Hold! not so ready with your jeers at men!
2.10: We know who once, and in what shrine with you—
2.11: the he-goats looked aside—the light nymphs laughed—
2.12: Ay, then, I warrant, when they saw me slash
2.13: micon's young vines and trees with spiteful hook.
2.14: Or here by these old beeches, when you broke
2.15: the bow and arrows of Damon; for you chafed
2.16: when first you saw them given to the boy,
2.17: cross-grained Menalcas, ay, and had you not
2.18: done him some mischief, would have chafed to death.
2.19: With thieves so daring, what can masters do?
2.20: Did I not see you, rogue, in ambush lie
2.21: for Damon's goat, while loud Lycisca barked?
2.22: And when I cried, “Where is he off to now?
2.26: whom I had conquered still to keep the goat.
2.27: Which in the piping-match my pipe had won!
2.28: You may not know it, but the goat was mine.
2.29: You out-pipe him? when had you ever pipe
2.30: wax-welded? in the cross-ways used you not
2.31: on grating straw some miserable tune
2.33: Well, then, shall we try our skill
2.34: each against each in turn? Lest you be loth,
2.35: I pledge this heifer; every day she comes
2.36: twice to the milking-pail, and feeds withal
2.37: two young ones at her udder: say you now
2.38: what you will stake upon the match with me.
2.39: Naught from the flock I'll venture, for at home
2.40: I have a father and a step-dame harsh,
2.41: and twice a day both reckon up the flock,
2.42: and one withal the kids. But I will stake,
2.43: seeing you are so mad, what you yourself
2.44: will own more priceless far—two beechen cups
2.45: by the divine art of Alcimedon
2.46: wrought and embossed, whereon a limber vine,
2.47: wreathed round them by the graver's facile tool,
2.49: Two figures, one Conon, in the midst he set,
2.50: and one—how call you him, who with his wand
2.51: marked out for all men the whole round of heaven,
2.52: that they who reap, or stoop behind the plough,
2.53: might know their several seasons? Nor as yet
2.54: have I set lip to them, but lay them by.
2.55: For me too wrought the same Alcimedon
2.56: a pair of cups, and round the handles wreathed
2.57: pliant acanthus, Orpheus in the midst,
2.58: the forests following in his wake; nor yet
2.60: Matched with a heifer, who would prate of cups?
2.61: You shall not balk me now; where'er you bid,
2.62: I shall be with you; only let us have
2.63: for auditor—or see, to serve our turn,
2.65: i'll see you play the challenger no more.
2.66: Out then with what you have; I shall not shrink,
2.67: nor budge for any man: only do you,
2.68: neighbour Palaemon, with your whole heart's skill—
2.69: for it is no slight matter—play your part.
2.70: Say on then, since on the greensward we sit,
2.71: and now is burgeoning both field and tree;
2.72: now is the forest green, and now the year
2.73: at fairest. Do you first, Damoetas, sing,
2.74: then you, Menalcas, in alternate strain:
2.75: alternate strains are to the Muses dear.
2.76: “From Jove the Muse began; Jove filleth all,
2.77: makes the earth fruitful, for my songs hath care.”
2.78: “Me Phoebus loves; for Phoebus his own gifts,
2.79: bays and sweet-blushing hyacinths, I keep.”
2.80: “Gay Galatea throws an apple at me,
2.81: then hies to the willows, hoping to be seen.”
2.82: “My dear Amyntas comes unasked to me;
2.83: not Delia to my dogs is better known.”
2.84: “Gifts for my love I've found; mine eyes have marked
2.85: where the wood-pigeons build their airy nests.”
2.86: “Ten golden apples have I sent my boy,
2.87: all that I could, to-morrow as many more.”
2.88: “What words to me, and uttered O how oft,
2.89: hath Galatea spoke! waft some of them,
2.90: ye winds, I pray you, for the gods to hear.”
2.92: that in your very heart you spurn me not,
2.93: if, while you hunt the boar, I guard the nets.”
2.95: send me your Phyllis; when for the young crops
2.96: I slay my heifer, you yourself shall come.”
2.97: “I am all hers; she wept to see me go,
2.98: and, lingering on the word, ‘farewell’ she said,
2.100: “Fell as the wolf is to the folded flock,
2.101: rain to ripe corn, Sirocco to the trees,
2.102: the wrath of Amaryllis is to me.”
2.103: “As moisture to the corn, to ewes with young
2.104: lithe willow, as arbute to the yeanling kids,
2.105: so sweet Amyntas, and none else, to me.”
2.106: “My Muse, although she be but country-bred,
2.107: is loved by Pollio: O Pierian Maids,
2.108: pray you, a heifer for your reader feed!”
2.109: “Pollio himself too doth new verses make:
2.110: feed ye a bull now ripe to butt with horn,
2.111: and scatter with his hooves the flying sand.”
2.112: “Who loves thee, Pollio, may he thither come
2.113: where thee he joys beholding; ay, for him
2.114: let honey flow, the thorn-bush spices bear.”
2.115: “Who hates not Bavius, let him also love
2.116: thy songs, O Maevius, ay, and therewithal
2.117: yoke foxes to his car, and he-goats milk.”
2.118: “You, picking flowers and strawberries that grow
2.119: so near the ground, fly hence, boys, get you gone!
2.120: There's a cold adder lurking in the grass.”
2.121: “Forbear, my sheep, to tread too near the brink;
2.122: yon bank is ill to trust to; even now
2.123: the ram himself, see, dries his dripping fleece!”
2.124: “Back with the she-goats, Tityrus, grazing there
2.125: so near the river! I, when time shall serve,
2.126: will take them all, and wash them in the pool.”
2.127: “Boys, get your sheep together; if the heat,
2.128: as late it did, forestall us with the milk,
2.129: vainly the dried-up udders shall we wring.”
2.130: “How lean my bull amid the fattening vetch!
2.131: Alack! alack! for herdsman and for herd!
2.132: It is the self-same love that wastes us both.”
2.133: “These truly—nor is even love the cause—
2.134: scarce have the flesh to keep their bones together
2.135: some evil eye my lambkins hath bewitched.”
2.136: “Say in what clime—and you shall be withal
2.137: my great Apollo—the whole breadth of heaven
2.138: opens no wider than three ells to view.”
2.139: “Say in what country grow such flowers as bear
2.140: the names of kings upon their petals writ,
2.141: and you shall have fair Phyllis for your own.”
2.142: Not mine betwixt such rivals to decide:
2.143: you well deserve the heifer, so does he,
2.144: with all who either fear the sweets of love,
2.145: or taste its bitterness. Now, boys, shut off
2.146: the sluices, for the fields have drunk their fill.

3.0: muses of Sicily , essay we now
3.1: a somewhat loftier task! Not all men love
3.2: coppice or lowly tamarisk: sing we woods,
3.3: woods worthy of a Consul let them be.
3.4: Now the last age by Cumae's Sibyl sung
3.5: has come and gone, and the majestic roll
3.7: justice returns, returns old Saturn's reign,
3.8: with a new breed of men sent down from heaven.
3.9: Only do thou, at the boy's birth in whom
3.10: the iron shall cease, the golden race arise,
3.11: befriend him, chaste Lucina; 'tis thine own
3.12: apollo reigns. And in thy consulate,
3.13: this glorious age, O Pollio, shall begin,
3.14: and the months enter on their mighty march.
3.15: Under thy guidance, whatso tracks remain
3.16: of our old wickedness, once done away,
3.17: shall free the earth from never-ceasing fear.
3.18: He shall receive the life of gods, and see
3.19: heroes with gods commingling, and himself
3.20: be seen of them, and with his father's worth
3.21: reign o'er a world at peace. For thee, O boy,
3.22: first shall the earth, untilled, pour freely forth
3.23: her childish gifts, the gadding ivy-spray
3.24: with foxglove and Egyptian bean-flower mixed,
3.26: untended, will the she-goats then bring home
3.27: their udders swollen with milk, while flocks afield
3.28: shall of the monstrous lion have no fear.
3.29: Thy very cradle shall pour forth for thee
3.30: caressing flowers. The serpent too shall die,
3.31: die shall the treacherous poison-plant, and far
3.32: and wide Assyrian spices spring. But soon
3.33: as thou hast skill to read of heroes' fame,
3.34: and of thy father's deeds, and inly learn
3.35: what virtue is, the plain by slow degrees
3.36: with waving corn-crops shall to golden grow,
3.37: from the wild briar shall hang the blushing grape,
3.38: and stubborn oaks sweat honey-dew. Nathless
3.39: yet shall there lurk within of ancient wrong
3.40: some traces, bidding tempt the deep with ships,
3.41: gird towns with walls, with furrows cleave the earth.
3.42: Therewith a second Tiphys shall there be,
3.43: her hero-freight a second Argo bear;
3.44: new wars too shall arise, and once again
3.45: some great Achilles to some Troy be sent.
3.46: Then, when the mellowing years have made thee man,
3.47: no more shall mariner sail, nor pine-tree bark
3.48: ply traffic on the sea, but every land
3.49: shall all things bear alike: the glebe no more
3.50: shall feel the harrow's grip, nor vine the hook;
3.51: the sturdy ploughman shall loose yoke from steer,
3.52: nor wool with varying colours learn to lie;
3.53: but in the meadows shall the ram himself,
3.54: now with soft flush of purple, now with tint
3.55: of yellow saffron, teach his fleece to shine.
3.56: While clothed in natural scarlet graze the lambs.
3.57: “Such still, such ages weave ye, as ye run,”
3.58: sang to their spindles the consenting Fates
3.60: Assume thy greatness, for the time draws nigh,
3.61: dear child of gods, great progeny of Jove!
3.62: See how it totters—the world's orbed might,
3.63: earth, and wide ocean, and the vault profound,
3.64: all, see, enraptured of the coming time!
3.65: Ah! might such length of days to me be given,
3.66: and breath suffice me to rehearse thy deeds,
3.67: nor Thracian Orpheus should out-sing me then,
3.68: nor Linus, though his mother this, and that
3.70: and Linus fair Apollo. Nay, though Pan,
3.71: with Arcady for judge, my claim contest,
3.72: with Arcady for judge great Pan himself
3.73: should own him foiled, and from the field retire.
3.74: Begin to greet thy mother with a smile,
3.75: o baby-boy! ten months of weariness
3.76: for thee she bore: O baby-boy, begin!
3.77: For him, on whom his parents have not smiled,
3.78: gods deem not worthy of their board or bed.

4.0: Why, Mopsus, being both together met,
4.1: you skilled to breathe upon the slender reeds,
4.2: I to sing ditties, do we not sit down
4.3: here where the elm-trees and the hazels blend?
4.4: You are the elder, 'tis for me to bide
4.5: your choice, Menalcas, whether now we seek
4.6: yon shade that quivers to the changeful breeze,
4.7: or the cave's shelter. Look you how the cave
4.8: is with the wild vine's clusters over-laced!
4.9: None but Amyntas on these hills of ours
4.14: good Mopsus, whether minded to sing aught
4.15: of Phyllis and her loves, or Alcon's praise,
4.16: or to fling taunts at Codrus. Come, begin,
4.17: while Tityrus watches o'er the grazing kids.
4.18: Nay, then, I will essay what late I carved
4.19: on a green beech-tree's rind, playing by turns,
4.20: and marking down the notes; then afterward
4.21: bid you Amyntas match them if he can.
4.22: As limber willow to pale olive yields,
4.23: as lowly Celtic nard to rose-buds bright,
4.24: so, to my mind, Amyntas yields to you.
4.25: But hold awhile, for to the cave we come.
4.26: “For Daphnis cruelly slain wept all the Nymphs—
4.27: ye hazels, bear them witness, and ye streams—
4.28: when she, his mother, clasping in her arms
4.29: the hapless body of the son she bare,
4.30: to gods and stars unpitying, poured her plaint.
4.31: Then, Daphnis, to the cooling streams were none
4.32: that drove the pastured oxen, then no beast
4.33: drank of the river, or would the grass-blade touch.
4.34: Nay, the wild rocks and woods then voiced the roar
4.35: of Afric lions mourning for thy death.
4.36: Daphnis, 'twas thou bad'st yoke to Bacchus' car
4.37: armenian tigresses, lead on the pomp
4.38: of revellers, and with tender foliage wreathe
4.39: the bending spear-wands. As to trees the vine
4.40: is crown of glory, as to vines the grape,
4.41: bulls to the herd, to fruitful fields the corn,
4.42: so the one glory of thine own art thou.
4.43: When the Fates took thee hence, then Pales' self,
4.44: and even Apollo, left the country lone.
4.45: Where the plump barley-grain so oft we sowed,
4.46: there but wild oats and barren darnel spring;
4.47: for tender violet and narcissus bright
4.48: thistle and prickly thorn uprear their heads.
4.49: Now, O ye shepherds, strew the ground with leaves,
4.50: and o'er the fountains draw a shady veil—
4.51: so Daphnis to his memory bids be done—
4.52: and rear a tomb, and write thereon this verse:
4.53: ‘I, Daphnis in the woods, from hence in fame
4.54: am to the stars exalted, guardian once
4.55: of a fair flock, myself more fair than they.’”
4.56: So is thy song to me, poet divine,
4.57: as slumber on the grass to weary limbs,
4.58: or to slake thirst from some sweet-bubbling rill
4.59: in summer's heat. Nor on the reeds alone,
4.60: but with thy voice art thou, thrice happy boy,
4.61: ranked with thy master, second but to him.
4.62: Yet will I, too, in turn, as best I may,
4.63: sing thee a song, and to the stars uplift
4.64: thy Daphnis—Daphnis to the stars extol,
4.67: what dearer could I deem? the boy himself
4.68: was worthy to be sung, and many a time
4.69: hath Stimichon to me your singing praised.
4.71: daphnis stands rapt before Olympus ' gate,
4.72: and sees beneath his feet the clouds and stars.
4.73: Wherefore the woods and fields, Pan, shepherd-folk,
4.74: and Dryad-maidens, thrill with eager joy;
4.75: nor wolf with treacherous wile assails the flock,
4.76: nor nets the stag: kind Daphnis loveth peace.
4.77: The unshorn mountains to the stars up-toss
4.78: voices of gladness; ay, the very rocks,
4.79: the very thickets, shout and sing, ‘A god,
4.80: a god is he, Menalcas’ Be thou kind,
4.81: propitious to thine own. Lo! altars four,
4.82: twain to thee, Daphnis, and to Phoebus twain
4.83: for sacrifice, we build; and I for thee
4.84: two beakers yearly of fresh milk afoam,
4.85: and of rich olive-oil two bowls, will set;
4.86: and of the wine-god's bounty above all,
4.87: if cold, before the hearth, or in the shade
4.88: at harvest-time, to glad the festal hour,
4.89: from flasks of Ariusian grape will pour
4.90: sweet nectar. Therewithal at my behest
4.91: shall Lyctian Aegon and Damoetas sing,
4.93: the dancing Satyrs. This, thy service due,
4.94: shalt thou lack never, both when we pay the Nymphs
4.95: our yearly vows, and when with lustral rites
4.96: the fields we hallow. Long as the wild boar
4.97: shall love the mountain-heights, and fish the streams,
4.98: while bees on thyme and crickets feed on dew,
4.99: thy name, thy praise, thine honour, shall endure.
4.100: Even as to Bacchus and to Ceres, so
4.101: to thee the swain his yearly vows shall make;
4.102: and thou thereof, like them, shalt quittance claim.”
4.103: How, how repay thee for a song so rare?
4.104: For not the whispering south-wind on its way
4.105: so much delights me, nor wave-smitten beach,
4.106: nor streams that race adown their bouldered beds.
4.107: First this frail hemlock-stalk to you I give,
4.108: which taught me “Corydon with love was fired
4.109: for fair Alexis,” ay, and this beside,
4.112: this shepherd's crook, which, howso hard he begged,
4.113: antigenes, then worthy to be loved,
4.114: prevailed not to obtain—with brass, you see,
4.115: and equal knots, Menalcas, fashioned fair!

5.0: first my Thalia stooped in sportive mood
5.1: to Syracusan strains, nor blushed within
5.2: the woods to house her. When I sought to tell
5.3: of battles and of kings, the Cynthian god
5.4: plucked at mine ear and warned me: “Tityrus,
5.5: beseems a shepherd-wight to feed fat sheep,
5.6: but sing a slender song.” Now, Varus, I—
5.7: for lack there will not who would laud thy deeds,
5.8: and treat of dolorous wars—will rather tune
5.9: to the slim oaten reed my silvan lay.
5.10: I sing but as vouchsafed me; yet even this
5.11: if, if but one with ravished eyes should read,
5.12: of thee, O Varus, shall our tamarisks
5.13: and all the woodland ring; nor can there be
5.14: a page more dear to Phoebus, than the page
5.15: where, foremost writ, the name of Varus stands.
5.16: Speed ye, Pierian Maids! Within a cave
5.17: young Chromis and Mnasyllos chanced to see
5.18: silenus sleeping, flushed, as was his wont,
5.19: with wine of yesterday. Not far aloof,
5.20: slipped from his head, the garlands lay, and there
5.21: by its worn handle hung a ponderous cup.
5.22: Approaching—for the old man many a time
5.23: had balked them both of a long hoped-for song—
5.24: garlands to fetters turned, they bind him fast.
5.25: Then Aegle, fairest of the Naiad-band,
5.26: aegle came up to the half-frightened boys,
5.27: came, and, as now with open eyes he lay,
5.28: with juice of blood-red mulberries smeared him o'er,
5.29: both brow and temples. Laughing at their guile,
5.30: and crying, “Why tie the fetters? loose me, boys;
5.31: enough for you to think you had the power;
5.32: now list the songs you wish for—songs for you,
5.34: Then might you see the wild things of the wood,
5.35: with Fauns in sportive frolic beat the time,
5.36: and stubborn oaks their branchy summits bow.
5.37: Not Phoebus doth the rude Parnassian crag
5.38: so ravish, nor Orpheus so entrance the heights
5.39: of Rhodope or Ismarus: for he sang
5.40: how through the mighty void the seeds were driven
5.41: of earth, air, ocean, and of liquid fire,
5.42: how all that is from these beginnings grew,
5.43: and the young world itself took solid shape,
5.44: then 'gan its crust to harden, and in the deep
5.45: shut Nereus off, and mould the forms of things
5.46: little by little; and how the earth amazed
5.47: beheld the new sun shining, and the showers
5.48: fall, as the clouds soared higher, what time the woods
5.49: 'gan first to rise, and living things to roam
5.50: scattered among the hills that knew them not.
5.51: Then sang he of the stones by Pyrrha cast,
5.52: of Saturn's reign, and of Prometheus' theft,
5.53: and the Caucasian birds, and told withal
5.54: nigh to what fountain by his comrades left
5.55: the mariners cried on Hylas till the shore
5.57: pasiphae with the love of her white bull—
5.58: happy if cattle-kind had never been!—
5.59: o ill-starred maid, what frenzy caught thy soul
5.60: the daughters too of Proetus filled the fields
5.61: with their feigned lowings, yet no one of them
5.62: of such unhallowed union e'er was fain
5.63: as with a beast to mate, though many a time
5.64: on her smooth forehead she had sought for horns,
5.65: and for her neck had feared the galling plough.
5.66: O ill-starred maid! thou roamest now the hills,
5.67: while on soft hyacinths he, his snowy side
5.68: reposing, under some dark ilex now
5.69: chews the pale herbage, or some heifer tracks
5.70: amid the crowding herd. Now close, ye Nymphs,
5.71: ye Nymphs of Dicte, close the forest-glades,
5.72: if haply there may chance upon mine eyes
5.73: the white bull's wandering foot-prints: him belike
5.74: following the herd, or by green pasture lured,
5.75: some kine may guide to the Gortynian stalls.
5.76: Then sings he of the maid so wonder-struck
5.77: with the apples of the Hesperids, and then
5.78: with moss-bound, bitter bark rings round the forms
5.79: of Phaethon's fair sisters, from the ground
5.80: up-towering into poplars. Next he sings
5.81: of Gallus wandering by Permessus' stream,
5.82: and by a sister of the Muses led
5.83: to the Aonian mountains, and how all
5.84: the choir of Phoebus rose to greet him; how
5.85: the shepherd Linus, singer of songs divine,
5.86: brow-bound with flowers and bitter parsley, spake:
5.87: “These reeds the Muses give thee, take them thou,
5.88: erst to the aged bard of Ascra given,
5.89: wherewith in singing he was wont to draw
5.90: time-rooted ash-trees from the mountain heights.
5.91: With these the birth of the Grynean grove
5.92: be voiced by thee, that of no grove beside
5.93: apollo more may boast him.” Wherefore speak
5.94: of Scylla, child of Nisus, who, 'tis said,
5.95: her fair white loins with barking monsters girt
5.96: vexed the Dulichian ships, and, in the deep
5.97: swift-eddying whirlpool, with her sea-dogs tore
5.98: the trembling mariners? or how he told
5.99: of the changed limbs of Tereus—what a feast,
5.100: what gifts, to him by Philomel were given;
5.101: how swift she sought the desert, with what wings
5.102: hovered in anguish o'er her ancient home?
5.103: All that, of old, Eurotas, happy stream,
5.104: heard, as Apollo mused upon the lyre,
5.105: and bade his laurels learn, Silenus sang;
5.106: till from Olympus , loth at his approach,
5.107: vesper, advancing, bade the shepherds tell
5.108: their tale of sheep, and pen them in the fold.

6.1: had sat him down; Thyrsis and Corydon
6.2: had gathered in the flock, Thyrsis the sheep,
6.3: and Corydon the she-goats swollen with milk—
6.4: both in the flower of age, Arcadians both,
6.5: ready to sing, and in like strain reply.
6.6: Hither had strayed, while from the frost I fend
6.7: my tender myrtles, the he-goat himself,
6.8: lord of the flock; when Daphnis I espy!
6.9: Soon as he saw me, “Hither haste,” he cried,
6.10: “O Meliboeus! goat and kids are safe;
6.11: and, if you have an idle hour to spare,
6.12: rest here beneath the shade. Hither the steers
6.13: will through the meadows, of their own free will,
6.14: untended come to drink. Here Mincius hath
6.15: with tender rushes rimmed his verdant banks,
6.16: and from yon sacred oak with busy hum
6.17: the bees are swarming.” What was I to do?
6.18: No Phyllis or Alcippe left at home
6.19: had I, to shelter my new-weaned lambs,
6.20: and no slight matter was a singing-bout
6.22: I let my business wait upon their sport.
6.23: So they began to sing, voice answering voice
6.25: the Muses then were minded to recall—
6.26: first Corydon, then Thyrsis in reply.
6.27: “Libethrian Nymphs, who are my heart's delight,
6.28: grant me, as doth my Codrus, so to sing—
6.29: next to Apollo he—or if to this
6.30: we may not all attain, my tuneful pipe
6.31: here on this sacred pine shall silent hang.”
6.33: your budding poet, so that Codrus burst
6.34: with envy: if he praise beyond my due,
6.35: then bind my brow with foxglove, lest his tongue
6.36: with evil omen blight the coming bard.”
6.37: “This bristling boar's head, Delian Maid, to thee,
6.38: with branching antlers of a sprightly stag,
6.39: young Micon offers: if his luck but hold,
6.41: with purple buskin, shall thy statue stand.”
6.42: “A bowl of milk, Priapus, and these cakes,
6.43: yearly, it is enough for thee to claim;
6.44: thou art the guardian of a poor man's plot.
6.45: Wrought for a while in marble, if the flock
6.46: at lambing time be filled,stand there in gold.”
6.48: sweeter than Hybla-thyme, more white than swans,
6.49: fairer than ivy pale, soon as the steers
6.50: shall from their pasture to the stalls repair,
6.51: if aught for Corydon thou carest, come.”
6.52: “Now may I seem more bitter to your taste
6.53: than herb Sardinian, rougher than the broom,
6.54: more worthless than strewn sea-weed, if to-day
6.55: hath not a year out-lasted! Fie for shame!
6.56: Go home, my cattle, from your grazing go!”
6.57: “Ye mossy springs, and grass more soft than sleep,
6.58: and arbute green with thin shade sheltering you,
6.59: ward off the solstice from my flock, for now
6.60: comes on the burning summer, now the buds
6.61: upon the limber vine-shoot 'gin to swell.”
6.62: “Here is a hearth, and resinous logs, here fire
6.63: unstinted, and doors black with ceaseless smoke.
6.64: Here heed we Boreas' icy breath as much
6.65: as the wolf heeds the number of the flock,
6.66: or furious rivers their restraining banks.”
6.68: and 'neath each tree lie strewn their several fruits,
6.69: now the whole world is smiling, but if fair
6.70: alexis from these hill-slopes should away,
6.71: even the rivers you would ; see run dry.”
6.72: “The field is parched, the grass-blades thirst to death
6.73: in the faint air; Liber hath grudged the hills
6.74: his vine's o'er-shadowing: should my Phyllis come,
6.75: green will be all the grove, and Jupiter
6.76: descend in floods of fertilizing rain.”
6.77: “The poplar doth Alcides hold most dear,
6.78: the vine Iacchus, Phoebus his own bays,
6.79: and Venus fair the myrtle: therewithal
6.80: phyllis doth hazels love, and while she loves,
6.81: myrtle nor bay the hazel shall out-vie.”
6.82: “Ash in the forest is most beautiful,
6.83: pine in the garden, poplar by the stream,
6.84: fir on the mountain-height; but if more oft
6.85: thou'ldst come to me, fair Lycidas, to thee
6.86: both forest-ash, and garden-pine should bow.”
6.87: These I remember, and how Thyrsis strove
6.88: for victory in vain. From that time forth
6.89: is Corydon still Corydon with us.

7.1: those shepherd-singers at whose rival strains
7.2: the heifer wondering forgot to graze,
7.3: the lynx stood awe-struck, and the flowing streams,
7.4: unwonted loiterers, stayed their course to hear—
7.6: their pastoral ditties, will I tell the tale.
7.7: Thou, whether broad Timavus' rocky banks
7.8: thou now art passing, or dost skirt the shore
7.9: of the Illyrian main,—will ever dawn
7.10: that day when I thy deeds may celebrate,
7.11: ever that day when through the whole wide world
7.12: I may renown thy verse—that verse alone
7.14: With thee began, to thee shall end, the strain.
7.15: Take thou these songs that owe their birth to thee,
7.16: and deign around thy temples to let creep
7.18: Scarce had night's chilly shade forsook the sky
7.19: what time to nibbling sheep the dewy grass
7.20: tastes sweetest, when, on his smooth shepherd-staff
7.21: of olive leaning, Damon thus began.
7.23: bring in the genial day, while I make moan
7.24: fooled by vain passion for a faithless bride,
7.25: for Nysa, and with this my dying breath
7.26: call on the gods, though little it bestead—
7.27: the gods who heard her vows and heeded not.
7.28: ‘Begin, my flute, with me Maenalian lays.’
7.29: Ever hath Maenalus his murmuring groves
7.30: and whispering pines, and ever hears the songs
7.31: of love-lorn shepherds, and of Pan, who first
7.32: brooked not the tuneful reed should idle lie.
7.34: Nysa to Mopsus given! what may not then
7.35: we lovers look for? soon shall we see mate
7.36: griffins with mares, and in the coming age
7.37: shy deer and hounds together come to drink.
7.39: Now, Mopsus, cut new torches, for they bring
7.40: your bride along; now, bridegroom, scatter nuts:
7.41: forsaking Oeta mounts the evening star!
7.43: O worthy of thy mate, while all men else
7.44: thou scornest, and with loathing dost behold
7.45: my shepherd's pipe, my goats, my shaggy brow,
7.46: and untrimmed beard, nor deem'st that any god
7.47: for mortal doings hath regard or care.
7.49: Once with your mother, in our orchard-garth,
7.50: a little maid I saw you—I your guide—
7.51: plucking the dewy apples. My twelfth year
7.52: I scarce had entered, and could barely reach
7.53: the brittle boughs. I looked, and I was lost;
7.54: a sudden frenzy swept my wits away.
7.56: Now know I what Love is: 'mid savage rocks
7.57: tmaros or Rhodope brought forth the boy,
7.58: or Garamantes in earth's utmost bounds—
7.59: no kin of ours, nor of our blood begot.
7.61: Fierce Love it was once steeled a mother's heart
7.62: with her own offspring's blood her hands to imbrue:
7.63: mother, thou too wert cruel; say wert thou
7.64: more cruel, mother, or more ruthless he?
7.65: Ruthless the boy, thou, mother, cruel too.
7.67: Now let the wolf turn tail and fly the sheep,
7.68: tough oaks bear golden apples, alder-trees
7.70: sweat with rich amber, and the screech-owl vie
7.71: in singing with the swan: let Tityrus
7.72: be Orpheus, Orpheus in the forest-glade,
7.73: arion 'mid his dolphins on the deep.
7.75: Yea, be the whole earth to mid-ocean turned!
7.76: Farewell, ye woodlands I from the tall peak
7.77: of yon aerial rock will headlong plunge
7.78: into the billows: this my latest gift,
7.79: from dying lips bequeathed thee, see thou keep.
7.80: Cease now, my flute, now cease Maenalian lays.’”
7.81: thus Damon: but do ye, Pierian Maids—
7.82: we cannot all do all things—tell me how
7.84: “Bring water, and with soft wool-fillet bind
7.85: these altars round about, and burn thereon
7.86: rich vervain and male frankincense, that I
7.87: may strive with magic spells to turn astray
7.89: there lacketh nothing save the power of song.
7.90: ‘Draw from the town, my songs, draw Daphnis home.’
7.91: Songs can the very moon draw down from heaven
7.92: circe with singing changed from human form
7.93: the comrades of Ulysses, and by song
7.94: is the cold meadow-snake, asunder burst.
7.96: These triple threads of threefold colour first
7.97: I twine about thee, and three times withal
7.98: around these altars do thine image bear:
7.99: uneven numbers are the god's delight.
7.101: Now, Amaryllis, ply in triple knots
7.102: the threefold colours; ply them fast, and say
7.103: this is the chain of Venus that I ply.
7.105: As by the kindling of the self-same fire
7.106: harder this clay, this wax the softer grows,
7.107: so by my love may Daphnis; sprinkle meal,
7.108: and with bitumen burn the brittle bays.
7.109: Me Daphnis with his cruelty doth burn,
7.110: I to melt cruel Daphnis burn this bay.
7.112: As when some heifer, seeking for her steer
7.113: through woodland and deep grove, sinks wearied out
7.114: on the green sedge beside a stream, love-lorn,
7.115: nor marks the gathering night that calls her home—
7.116: as pines that heifer, with such love as hers
7.117: may Daphnis pine, and I not care to heal.
7.119: These relics once, dear pledges of himself,
7.120: the traitor left me, which, O earth, to thee
7.121: here on this very threshold I commit—
7.122: pledges that bind him to redeem the debt.
7.124: These herbs of bane to me did Moeris give,
7.125: in Pontus culled, where baneful herbs abound.
7.126: With these full oft have I seen Moeris change
7.127: to a wolf's form, and hide him in the woods,
7.128: oft summon spirits from the tomb's recess,
7.129: and to new fields transport the standing corn.
7.131: Take ashes, Amaryllis, fetch them forth,
7.132: and o'er your head into the running brook
7.133: fling them, nor look behind: with these will
7.134: upon the heart of Daphnis make essay.
7.135: Nothing for gods, nothing for songs cares he.
7.137: Look, look I the very embers of themselves
7.138: have caught the altar with a flickering flame,
7.139: while I delay to fetch them: may the sign
7.140: prove lucky! something it must mean, for sure,
7.141: and Hylax on the threshold 'gins to bark!
7.142: May we believe it, or are lovers still
7.145: daphnis is coming from the town, give o'er.”

8.0: Say whither, Moeris?—Make you for the town,
8.3: we have lived to see, what never yet we feared,
8.4: an interloper own our little farm,
8.5: and say, “Be off, you former husbandmen!
8.6: These fields are mine.” Now, cowed and out of heart,
8.7: since Fortune turns the whole world upside down,
8.8: we are taking him—ill luck go with the same!—
8.11: that where the hills first draw from off the plain,
8.12: and the high ridge with gentle slope descends,
8.13: down to the brook-side and the broken crests
8.14: of yonder veteran beeches, all the land
8.15: was by the songs of your Menalcas saved.
8.16: Heard it you had, and so the rumour ran,
8.17: but 'mid the clash of arms, my Lycidas,
8.18: our songs avail no more than, as 'tis said,
8.19: doves of Dodona when an eagle comes.
8.20: Nay, had I not, from hollow ilex-bole
8.21: warned by a raven on the left, cut short
8.22: the rising feud, nor I, your Moeris here,
8.23: no, nor Menalcas, were alive to-day.
8.24: Alack! could any of so foul a crime
8.25: be guilty? Ah! how nearly, thyself,
8.26: reft was the solace that we had in thee,
8.27: Menalcas! Who then of the Nymphs had sung,
8.28: or who with flowering herbs bestrewn the ground,
8.29: and o'er the fountains drawn a leafy veil?—
8.30: who sung the stave I filched from you that day
8.31: to Amaryllis wending, our hearts' joy?—
8.32: “While I am gone, 'tis but a little way,
8.33: feed, Tityrus, my goats, and, having fed,
8.34: drive to the drinking-pool, and, as you drive,
8.35: beware the he-goat; with his horn he butts.“
8.36: Ay, or to Varus that half-finished lay,
8.37: “Varus, thy name, so still our Mantua live—
8.38: Mantua to poor Cremona all too near—
8.39: shall singing swans bear upward to the stars.”
8.40: So may your swarms Cyrnean yew-trees shun,
8.41: your kine with cytisus their udders swell,
8.42: begin, if aught you have. The Muses made
8.43: me too a singer; I too have sung; the swains
8.44: call me a poet, but I believe them not:
8.45: for naught of mine, or worthy Varius yet
8.46: or Cinna deem I, but account myself
8.47: a cackling goose among melodious swans.
8.48: 'Twas in my thought to do so, Lycidas;
8.49: even now was I revolving silently
8.50: if this I could recall—no paltry song:
8.51: “Come, Galatea, what pleasure is 't to play
8.52: amid the waves? Here glows the Spring, here earth
8.53: beside the streams pours forth a thousand flowers;
8.54: here the white poplar bends above the cave,
8.55: and the lithe vine weaves shadowy covert: come,
8.56: leave the mad waves to beat upon the shore.”
8.57: What of the strain I heard you singing once
8.58: on a clear night alone? the notes I still
8.59: remember, could I but recall the words.
8.60: “Why, Daphnis, upward gazing, do you mark
8.61: the ancient risings of the Signs? for look
8.62: where Dionean Caesar's star comes forth
8.63: in heaven, to gladden all the fields with corn,
8.64: and to the grape upon the sunny slopes
8.65: her colour bring! Now, the pears;
8.66: so shall your children's children pluck their fruit.”
8.67: Time carries all things, even our wits, away.
8.68: Oft, as a boy, I sang the sun to rest,
8.69: but all those songs are from my memory fled,
8.70: and even his voice is failing Moeris now;
8.71: the wolves eyed Moeris first: but at your wish
8.72: Menalcas will repeat them oft enow.
8.73: Your pleas but linger out my heart's desire:
8.74: now all the deep is into silence hushed,
8.75: and all the murmuring breezes sunk to sleep.
8.76: We are half-way thither, for Bianor's tomb
8.77: begins to show: here, Moeris, where the hinds
8.78: are lopping the thick leafage, let us sing.
8.79: Set down the kids, yet shall we reach the town;
8.80: or, if we fear the night may gather rain
8.81: ere we arrive, then singing let us go,
8.82: our way to lighten; and, that we may thus
8.83: go singing, I will case you of this load.
8.84: Cease, boy, and get we to the work in hand:
8.85: we shall sing better when himself is come.

9.0: This now, the very latest of my toils,
9.1: vouchsafe me, Arethusa! needs must I
9.2: sing a brief song to Gallus—brief, but yet
9.3: such as Lycoris' self may fitly read.
9.4: Who would not sing for Gallus? So, when thou
9.6: may Doris blend no bitter wave with thine,
9.7: begin! The love of Gallus be our theme,
9.8: and the shrewd pangs he suffered, while, hard by,
9.9: the flat-nosed she-goats browse the tender brush.
9.10: We sing not to deaf ears; no word of ours
9.11: but the woods echo it. What groves or lawns
9.12: held you, ye Dryad-maidens, when for love—
9.13: love all unworthy of a loss so dear—
9.14: Gallus lay dying? for neither did the slopes
9.15: of Pindus or Parnassus stay you then,
9.17: even the laurels and the tamarisks wept;
9.18: for him, outstretched beneath a lonely rock,
9.19: wept pine-clad Maenalus, and the flinty crags
9.20: of cold Lycaeus. The sheep too stood around—
9.21: of us they feel no shame, poet divine;
9.22: nor of the flock be thou ashamed: even fair
9.23: Adonis by the rivers fed his sheep—
9.24: came shepherd too, and swine-herd footing slow,
9.26: Menalcas. All with one accord exclaim:
9.27: “From whence this love of thine?” Apollo came;
9.28: “Gallus, art mad?” he cried, “thy bosom's care
9.30: Silvanus came, with rural honours crowned;
9.31: the flowering fennels and tall lilies shook
9.32: before him. Yea, and our own eyes beheld
9.33: pan, god of Arcady, with blood-red juice
9.34: of the elder-berry, and with vermilion, dyed.
9.35: “Wilt ever make an end?” quoth he, “behold
9.36: love recks not aught of it: his heart no more
9.37: with tears is sated than with streams the grass,
9.38: bees with the cytisus, or goats with leaves.”
9.39: “Yet will ye sing, Arcadians, of my woes
9.40: upon your mountains,” sadly he replied—
9.41: “Arcadians, that alone have skill to sing.
9.42: O then how softly would my ashes rest,
9.43: if of my love, one day, your flutes should tell!
9.44: And would that I, of your own fellowship,
9.45: or dresser of the ripening grape had been,
9.46: or guardian of the flock! for surely then,
9.47: let Phyllis, or Amyntas, or who else,
9.48: bewitch me—what if swart Amyntas be?
9.49: Dark is the violet, dark the hyacinth—
9.50: among the willows, 'neath the limber vine,
9.51: reclining would my love have lain with me,
9.52: Phyllis plucked garlands, or Amyntas sung.
9.53: Here are cool springs, soft mead and grove, Lycoris;
9.54: here might our lives with time have worn away.
9.55: But me mad love of the stern war-god holds
9.56: armed amid weapons and opposing foes.
9.57: Whilst thou—Ah! might I but believe it not!—
9.58: alone without me, and from home afar,
9.59: look'st upon Alpine snows and frozen Rhine .
9.60: Ah! may the frost not hurt thee, may the sharp
9.61: and jagged ice not wound thy tender feet!
9.62: I will depart, re-tune the songs I framed
9.63: in verse Chalcidian to the oaten reed
9.64: of the Sicilian swain. Resolved am I
9.65: in the woods, rather, with wild beasts to couch,
9.66: and bear my doom, and character my love
9.67: upon the tender tree-trunks: they will grow,
9.68: and you, my love, grow with them. And meanwhile
9.69: I with the Nymphs will haunt Mount Maenalus,
9.70: or hunt the keen wild boar. No frost so cold
9.71: but I will hem with hounds thy forest-glades,
9.72: parthenius. Even now, methinks, I range
9.73: o'er rocks, through echoing groves, and joy to launch
9.74: Cydonian arrows from a Parthian bow.—
9.75: as if my madness could find healing thus,
9.76: or that god soften at a mortal's grief!
9.77: Now neither Hamadryads, no, nor songs
9.78: delight me more: ye woods, away with you!
9.79: No pangs of ours can change him; not though we
9.80: in the mid-frost should drink of Hebrus ' stream,
9.81: and in wet winters face Sithonian snows,
9.82: or, when the bark of the tall elm-tree bole
9.83: of drought is dying, should, under Cancer's Sign,
9.84: in Aethiopian deserts drive our flocks.
9.85: Love conquers all things; yield we too to love!”
9.86: These songs, Pierian Maids, shall it suffice
9.87: your poet to have sung, the while he sat,
9.88: and of slim mallow wove a basket fine:
9.89: to Gallus ye will magnify their worth,
9.90: Gallus, for whom my love grows hour by hour,
9.91: as the green alder shoots in early Spring.
9.92: Come, let us rise: the shade is wont to be
9.93: baneful to singers; baneful is the shade
9.94: cast by the juniper, crops sicken too
9.95: in shade. Now homeward, having fed your fill—
9.96: eve's star is rising—go, my she-goats, go.

edition: Virgil, creator; Greenough, J. B. (James Bradstreet), 1833-1901, editor
